BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 13, 1922
THE HONOR SYSTEM
The Honor System has long been an accepted institution at
Hopkins, but for the benefit of the new men a few words are in
order at this time. The Honor System places the individual on his
honor not to cheat in examinations, quizzes, laboratory or home
work. This means that all written work presented as that of the
author must be original. Of course, in the last two cases a certain
amount of co-operation is allowable, but this privilege should not be
taken advantage of unfairly. The Honor System is therefore simply
an expression of the belief that every student at the University is a
gentleman and will conduct himself as such under all circumstances.
The Honor System also presupposes, however, that, in addition
its rules, each student will take sufficient pride in the
observing
to
personnel of his Alma Mater to report arty infringement upon it
which he may observe. That this be done is vitally essential for the
success of the system. No one likes to report a fellow student, but
when the interest of the college demands it, personal objections must
be overcome. A man who cheats is one of the lowest specimens of the
human race and if he cheats at college he will cheat in business or in
whatever line of work he goes into upon graduation. It is not right
that such a man should bear the endorsement of Johns Hopkins, and
it is up to each individual student to see that he does not receive
this honor.
The Honor System is familiar to a number of students since
they have had it in prep school. Some of the students, however,
come from schools in which "cribbing," while not encouraged, is not
frowned upon severely by the students themselves. These students
must remember that at college an entirely different attitude is taken
and govern themselves accordingly.
Occasionally a man has proved himself unworthy of the trust
imposed upon him by the Honor System, and his connection with the
University has therefore been severed. We are able to state that
the percentage of these cases has been very small in the past, and
we trust that even this small percentage will be decreased in th,..;
future.

A NEED FULFILLED
The proposed Publicity Board, to be formed for the purpose of
spreading undergraduate propaganda throughout the country, will
fill a long-felt need. Hopkins is the best known American institution
of learning in Europe and is well known in the United States; this
reputation, however, is due to the high standard of the Medical and
Graduate Schools. The scholastic standing of this College of Arts
and Sciences and of the Engineering School, coupled with the rapid
strides made by the undergraduates within the last few years in the
development of college life entitles these schools to almost equal
recognition. Still the citizens of Baltimore and Maryland, and prep
school graduates in particular seem oblivious to the fact that there
is an undergraduate body at Hopkins. If the Publicity Board can
bring this fact to their attention it will be doing Hopkins an enormous service.

OUR NEXT ISSUE
The next issue of the News-Letter will be dedicated to Woodrow
Wilson and will appear on Monday as this day is to be observed
throughout the country as Wilson Day. The issue will contain special articles on our noted alumnus and should be of exceptional interest to all connected with the University.

The Debating Council has announced that the annual JuniorSenior Debate for the Adams
Trophy will be held oil Saturday
evening, the twenty-first of January. The subject for the debate
will be:
Resolved, That the United
States Government shall own and
operate the coal resources of this
country."
The judges have not as yet been
appointed, but the teams representing the two classes have been selected. The Senior team is made
up of Dorsey Watkins, Edward
Putzel and Adolphus Emmert. The
Junior team will be composed of
John Stump, Parker Williams and
Breslau. The Council has appointed Charles Murbury to manage the
debate and Ives and Smallwood as
his assistants.
The Council received a communication from the University of
Maryland several days ago concerning a date for a debate for .some
time in the spring. No reply has
been made yet, as the Council is
waiting for a reply from the University of Richmond, who requested a date some time ago.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 13, 1922
THE HONOR SYSTEM
The Honor System has long been an accepted institution at
Hopkins, but for the benefit of the new men a few words are in
order at this time. The Honor System places the individual on his
honor not to cheat in examinations, quizzes, laboratory or home
work. This means that all written work presented as that of the
author must be original. Of course, in the last two cases a certain
amount of co-operation is allowable, but this privilege should not be
taken advantage of unfairly. The Honor System is therefore simply
an expression of the belief that every student at the University is a
gentleman and will conduct himself as such under all circumstances.
The Honor System also presupposes, however, that, in addition
its rules, each student will take sufficient pride in the
observing
to
personnel of his Alma Mater to report arty infringement upon it
which he may observe. That this be done is vitally essential for the
success of the system. No one likes to report a fellow student, but
when the interest of the college demands it, personal objections must
be overcome. A man who cheats is one of the lowest specimens of the
human race and if he cheats at college he will cheat in business or in
whatever line of work he goes into upon graduation. It is not right
that such a man should bear the endorsement of Johns Hopkins, and
it is up to each individual student to see that he does not receive
this honor.
The Honor System is familiar to a number of students since
they have had it in prep school. Some of the students, however,
come from schools in which "cribbing," while not encouraged, is not
frowned upon severely by the students themselves. These students
must remember that at college an entirely different attitude is taken
and govern themselves accordingly.
Occasionally a man has proved himself unworthy of the trust
imposed upon him by the Honor System, and his connection with the
University has therefore been severed. We are able to state that
the percentage of these cases has been very small in the past, and
we trust that even this small percentage will be decreased in th,..;
future.

A NEED FULFILLED
The proposed Publicity Board, to be formed for the purpose of
spreading undergraduate propaganda throughout the country, will
fill a long-felt need. Hopkins is the best known American institution
of learning in Europe and is well known in the United States; this
reputation, however, is due to the high standard of the Medical and
Graduate Schools. The scholastic standing of this College of Arts
and Sciences and of the Engineering School, coupled with the rapid
strides made by the undergraduates within the last few years in the
development of college life entitles these schools to almost equal
recognition. Still the citizens of Baltimore and Maryland, and prep
school graduates in particular seem oblivious to the fact that there
is an undergraduate body at Hopkins. If the Publicity Board can
bring this fact to their attention it will be doing Hopkins an enormous service.

OUR NEXT ISSUE
The next issue of the News-Letter will be dedicated to Woodrow
Wilson and will appear on Monday as this day is to be observed
throughout the country as Wilson Day. The issue will contain special articles on our noted alumnus and should be of exceptional interest to all connected with the University.

The Debating Council has announced that the annual JuniorSenior Debate for the Adams
Trophy will be held oil Saturday
evening, the twenty-first of January. The subject for the debate
will be:
Resolved, That the United
States Government shall own and
operate the coal resources of this
country."
The judges have not as yet been
appointed, but the teams representing the two classes have been selected. The Senior team is made
up of Dorsey Watkins, Edward
Putzel and Adolphus Emmert. The
Junior team will be composed of
John Stump, Parker Williams and
Breslau. The Council has appointed Charles Murbury to manage the
debate and Ives and Smallwood as
his assistants.
The Council received a communication from the University of
Maryland several days ago concerning a date for a debate for .some
time in the spring. No reply has
been made yet, as the Council is
waiting for a reply from the University of Richmond, who requested a date some time ago.
